data.title: Philippe Petit to mark 50 years since Twin Towers high-wire walk
data.meta_description: The high-wire artist, who crossed a tightrope between the Twin Towers in 1974, will mark the anniversary with two performances in Morningside Heights.
data.text:
Philippe Petit remembers it like it was yesterday. On Aug. 7, 1974, he made an illegal high-wire walk 1,350 feet above the ground between the Twin Towers.

The French high-wire artist will look back on his 131-foot walk between the buildings during a show called "Towering." The event will take place on Aug. 7 and Aug. 8 at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

âEvery detail, the wind, the vibration of the cable. Itâs in my body and soul, you know, itâs interesting, 50 years later,â he said.

Petit has been an artist-in-residence at the cathedral for more than 42 years. He will walk across the nave of the enormous Morningside Heights cathedral 20 feet above the ground.

âI will have a big stage underneath the wire and audience on both sides, but the thing is my friend Sting will play and sing while I am on the wire,â he said.

Sting, singer, songwriter and musician, will perform a world premiere of the song he wrote about Petitâs walk between the towers, which were destroyed during the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

Petit says he has been asked about his thoughts on that day.

âI cannot really compare the loss of 9/11, the loss of two buildings, with the loss of thousands of human lives. You cannot mix that up, so I let people imagine how I felt that day,â he said.

Petit says the performances are a celebration of his accomplishment at the buildings, which just like him, became known worldwide after his feat.

A documentary on the walk called âMan on Wireâ was released in 2008, and a feature film called âThe Walkâ in 2015. At the age of 74, Petit says he has no plans to retire anytime soon.

âIâm not a daredevil. Iâm the opposite. I am somebody who wants to affirm life and inspire people to look up, look at the birds and start flying,â he said.
